quoteLast: that we approached Jaffa, and in an hour’s time we anchored close to the port. Boats immediately came off.
title: Travels of Lady Hester Stanhope, Volume 1 (of 3)
author: Stanhope, Hester, Lady, 1776-1839; Meryon, Charles Lewis, 1783-1877 [Editor]

quoteTime: About four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , Mr Banks and his party returned, and gave us an account of their expedition. Having proceeded about three leagues among swamps and mangroves, they went up into the country, which they found to differ but little from what they had seen before: They pursued their course therefore up the river, which at length was contracted into a narrow channel, and was bounded, not by swamps and mangroves, but by steep banks, that were covered with trees of a most beautiful verdure, among which was that which in the West Indies is called _Mohoe_, or the bark tree, the _hibiscus tiliaceus_; the land
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels — Volume 13
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: . It was quite unexpected, though he had not enjoyed his usual health for some weeks before. He fell down in the hall, just as he was returning from a walk, and died within two hours. He never spoke or recognised any one after his seizure."
title: The Gerrard Street Mystery and Other Weird Tales
author: Dent, John Charles, 1841-1888

quoteFirst: We took the train at Sydney at
quoteLast: .  It was American in one way, for we had a most rational sleeping car; also the car was clean and fine and new--nothing about it to suggest the rolling stock of the continent of Europe.  But our baggage was weighed, and extra weight charged for.  That was continental.  Continental and troublesome.
title: The Entire Project Gutenberg Works of Mark Twain
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910

quoteFirst: B. Pollok M’Call, Commanding the 5th Battn., wrote: “Whilst leading his men
quoteLast: on 12th July he was struck in the heart. He was immediately carried down and at once attended to by our doctor. The doctor told me he was afraid he had no chance, as he feared a large blood-vessel was severed.
title: The Roll of Honour, Volume 1
author: Ruvigny et Raineval, Melville Henry Massue, marquis de, 1868-1921

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
title: Collection of Nebraska Pioneer Reminiscences
author: Daughters of the American Revolution. Nebraska

quoteFirst: Merwin went back to his little bare office and plaited at his quirt again.
quoteTime: About four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: he went to the First National Bank and leaned over the railing of Longley’s desk.
title: Heart of the West
author: Henry, O., 1862-1910

quoteFirst: However, as I was stepping into my boat, some canoes appeared, and I came on shore again, and found they were the Indian deputies who were expected. This I thought a very happy incident for me; and having received proper powers and instructions I set out in good spirits from Cedar Point,[6] in Lake Erie, on the 26th of August, 1764,
quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , at the same time that the army proceeded for Detroit. My escort consisted of Godefroi, and another Canadian, two servants, twelve Indians, our allies, and five Mohawks, with a boat in which were our provisions, who were to attend us to the swifts of the Miamis river, about ten leagues distant, and then return to the army.
title: Journals of Conrad Weiser (1748), George Croghan (1750-1765), Christian Frederick Post (1758), and Thomas Morris (1764)
author: Thwaites, Reuben Gold, 1853-1913 [Editor]; Croghan, George, 1720?-1782; Morris, Thomas, 1732?-1818?; Post, Christian Frederick, 1710?-1785; Weiser, Conrad, 1696-1760

quoteFirst: On the first day of the new year, (the orientals follow the old style, which is twelve days later,)
quoteLast: , while we were assembled at the Mission-house, and engaged in celebrating the Lord's Supper, there was a very severe earthquake; at first a sudden shock, then a momentary pause, then a rocking motion, so that the arms of nearly every person were involuntarily extended to preserve their balance.
title:
